column1: Publish fabric-chaintool binary to nexus repository
column29:
publish fabric-chaintool binary to nexus release URL. Follow the below process to trigger the release chaintool binary

-- Trigger fabric-chaintool job after tag is created in fabric-chaintool git repository

-- Check the chaintool version number, if not SNAPSHOT

    – publish chaintool.tar.gz to [https://nexus.hyperledger.org/content/repositories/releases/] URL

    – If SNAPSHOT, publish snapshot version to [https://nexus.hyperledger.org/content/repositories/snapshots/]

column1: chaintool crash when protoc/protoc-gen-go missing
column29:
We should not crash, but report a helpful error message.

 

Possible optimization: We could probably auto-install protoc-gen-go if it is missing (e.g. "go get ../protoc-gen-go")

column1: [SECURITY] Differentiated CA & TLS cert SDK examples & examples/cluster client.config consumption
column29:
The fabric-chaintool examples previously capable of consuming the client.config emitted by fabric/examples/cluster *no longer function*

These examples stopped working after the merge/resolution of --FAB-4626---. The *fabric-chaintool*, or a *fabric-sdk* repo, should be created that is able to consume this client.config and perform install, instantiates and invokes against Hyperledger Fabric v1.0.0-rc1.

That is, given the latest merges to v1.0.0-rc1, how difficult is it to get these examples to work (again?), etc.

column1: Example02 BalanceResult protobuf encode/decode crash
column29:
h1. Issue

Creating an account with a balance of 0, by init or by transaction, results in a crash when attempting to query the balance.

```
$ node ./out/example02.js -c deploy -n org.hyperledger.chaincode.example02 --port 5000 --args '{"partyA":{"entity":"a", "value":100}, "partyB":{"entity":"b", "value":0}}'
Running deploy({"partyA":{"entity":"a","value":100},"partyB":{"entity":"b","value":0}})
HTTP POST: http://localhost:5000 - {"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"deploy","params":{"type":3,"chaincodeID":{"name":"org.hyperledger.chaincode.example02"},"ctorMsg":{"function":"init","args":["CgUKAWEQZBIDCgFi"]}},"id":"1"}
Response: {:result {:status OK, :message org.hyperledger.chaincode.example02}}
$ node ./out/example02.js -n org.hyperledger.chaincode.example02 --port 5000 -c check-balance --args '{"id":"b"}'
Running check-balance({"id":"b"})
HTTP POST: http://localhost:5000 - {"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"query","params":{"type":3,"chaincodeID":{"name":"org.hyperledger.chaincode.example02"},"ctorMsg":{"function":"org.hyperledger.chaincode.example02/query/1","args":["CgFi"]}},"id":"1"}

/LSEG/chaintool/examples/example02/client/rest/cljs/node_modules/protobufjs/node_modules/bytebuffer/dist/bytebuffer-node.js:346
            throw TypeError("Illegal buffer");
                  ^
TypeError: Illegal buffer
    at TypeError (native)
    at Function.module.exports.ByteBuffer.wrap (/LSEG/chaintool/examples/example02/client/rest/cljs/node_modules/protobufjs/node_modules/bytebuffer/dist/bytebuffer-node.js:346:19)
    at Function.Message.decode (/LSEG/chaintool/examples/example02/client/rest/cljs/node_modules/protobufjs/dist/protobuf.js:2930:84)
    at Message.decode64 (/LSEG/chaintool/examples/example02/client/rest/cljs/node_modules/protobufjs/dist/protobuf.js:2986:36)
    at /LSEG/chaintool/examples/example02/client/rest/cljs/out/example02/core.cljs:40:69
    at IncomingMessage.<anonymous> (/LSEG/chaintool/examples/example02/client/rest/cljs/out/example02/rpc.cljs:13:25)
    at IncomingMessage.emit (events.js:107:17)
    at IncomingMessage.Readable.read (_stream_readable.js:373:10)
    at flow (_stream_readable.js:750:26)
    at resume_ (_stream_readable.js:730:3)
```
h1. Discussion:

About the 0 balance issue @jranz303 found, it seems to be a base64 encoding/decoding issue. When I try to initialize with a zero balance, for example: `{"partyA":{"entity":"a", "value":100}, "partyB":{"entity":"b", "value":0}}`, the base64 encoded args are: `CgUKAWEQZBIDCgFi` When I decode that, I get something like:

```

ad
b
```

The d corresponds to ASCII value 100, which seems like an odd way to encode it but that’s what appears to be happening. ASCII 0 is NULL, so I think what’s happening is on decoding, ByteBuffer is hitting this line for account b’s amount:

```
if (buffer === null || typeof buffer !== 'object')
            throw TypeError("Illegal buffer”);
```

---

interesting
what should be happening is a clean pipeline from protobuf->binary->base64 and back out again
my guess is protobuf elided the entire message structure when the value of zero was presented
what was the base64 in the case of 0?

---

I’m not exactly sure.
Args: `{"partyA":{"entity":"a", "value":100}}`
Base64: `CgUKAWEQZA==`

Args: `{"partyA":{"entity":"a", "value":0}}`
Base64: `CgMKAWE=`

---

my guess is whats happening here is something along the lines of `protobuf.encode(BalanceResult{0]).len == 0` and `base64(null) -> decode64` breaks somewhere
column104: 04/Jul/18 10:15 PM;mastersingh24;Moving to future.  If they actually get done, can assign the fix version then;;;

column1: Platform.go decodes chaincode path from spec without validation
column29:
Currently, when install/instantiate chaincode, HLF doesn't do any checking on the chaincode path, which is passed in the spec by user request. It can be arbitrary string in theory.
  
 At [https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/core/chaincode/platforms/golang/platform.go#L466], the path is decoded directly from spec without any validation.

After that, the code runs the following cmd to build out that chaincode binary:

  ```go
 "GOPATH=/chaincode/input:$GOPATH go build -tags \"%s\" %s -o /chaincode/output/chaincode %s", gotags, ldflagsOpt, pkgname)

```
  
1. Then user may add arbitrary character into the chaincode path. I've tested that the ".." in path will work, which may allow user to build out a chaincode binary to call with other person's chaincode content.


2. A another case is that if users can add "-" at the head of the path, there will trigger an instantiation error, as the "go build" cmd will trigger the path as an unknown building flag. The error msg look like
  
 UTC [chaincode-platform] func1 -> ERRO 032 [0m Failed to generate platform-specific docker build: Error returned from build: 2 "flag provided but not defined: -testinjection/chaincode_example02
column104: 29/Nov/17 3:57 AM;dhuseby;This needs to be confirmed.  Validating all input is a commandment of secure programming, so this needs to be fixed.  It's severity level seems to be fairly low to me and doesn't warrant an advisory since it is mostly an insider attack vector.;;;
column105: 19/Jan/18 5:50 AM;dhuseby;This is a high security bug that hasn't been touched since the end of November.  What's going on with this?;;;
column106:
27/Jan/18 3:57 AM;mastersingh24;I thought I had commented on this one - my bad.

I do not believe that this is a high security bug:

1) Installation of chaincode is an administrative action.  Before installing any chaincode, users/admins should actually inspect the contents of the chaincode package.

2) There is a signed chaincode package which should be used for production systems.  This should be used to enforce the inspection workflow.

3) Nothing bad actually happens here.  The result of all of this is that the chaincode will not launch.  And even if people install a bad package, they simply need later install an updated package and upgrade the chaincode to get it running;;;
column107: 30/Jan/18 6:57 AM;dhuseby;I'm OK with downgrading this bug per your comment.  My only concern is that with #1 you're basically saying that all operators will have to have the capability of inspecting the chaincode source code and making sense of it.  I could think of a consortium situation where one member recommends installing an updated chaincode and all of the other members just blindly install it.  I guess we can't fix user error.  Maybe we need to make sure the end user is aware of the danger of running un-reviewed chaincode.;;;
column108: 30/Jan/18 6:59 AM;dhuseby;Gari, I'm not sure you addressed the bug as described, unless I don't fully grok the report.  It sounds to me like an unvalidated path bug.  Are you saying that the path will have to point to a signed chaincode bundle for anything to actually be installed/run?;;;

column1: "chaintool build" fails on OSX
column29:
{noformat}
[GO] go build -o /Users/jmcnevin/Source/fabric-chaintool/examples/parameterless/build/bin/org.hyperledger.chaincode.example.parameterless-0.1-SNAPSHOT -ldflags -linkmode external -extldflags '-static' chaincode
Using GOPATH /Users/jmcnevin/Source/fabric-chaintool/examples/parameterless/build/deps:/Users/jmcnevin/Source/fabric-chaintool/examples/parameterless/build:/Users/jmcnevin/Source/fabric-chaintool/examples/parameterless:/Users/jmcnevin/go
Error: # chaincode
/usr/local/Cellar/go/1.8.3/libexec/pkg/tool/darwin_amd64/link: running clang failed: exit status 1
ld: library not found for -lcrt0.o
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
{noformat}
column104:
29/Aug/17 1:15 AM;ecb;This is a fundamental limitation of OS X / MacOS (it is *not* a clang thang). The required crt0.o isn't provided by Xcode and friends. Depending on the underlying rational for -static linking we can:

1) Stop doing -static  altogether (probably wisest)

2) Stop doing it on OSX

3) Do a "partial" static link on OSX using something like "{{-static-libgcc -static-libstdc++"}};;;
column105:
29/Aug/17 1:38 AM;ecb;addendum:

On OS X the best you can do is "-static-libstdc++" Statically linking against libgcc is simply verboten.;;;

column1: stale chaintool README in fabric-chaintool samples
column29: README under https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/tree/master/examples/example02 appears to be stale.  Probably other samples under https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaintool/tree/master/examples are stale too.

column1: Init() function is exposed to clients for chaintool based chaincode
column29: A client could technically invoke the Init() function of a chaincode by crafting a function expression like "appinit/fcn/1".   This should not be allowed.

column1: add missing CCBY license to all .md and .rst files
chaintool build fails when comment is above composite type field
chaintool::package crash if imported package is missing
column29: Running "chaintool package" on a project with missing imports in the $GOPATH will result in a crash with a very cryptic stack trace.  Instead, we should inform the user what is actually wrong with their project.

column1: "chaintool inspect" does not work on v1.0
column29: This command relies on the now defunct REST endpoint in the peer.  This needs to be ported to v1.0 facilities, either via raw GRPC or the java-sdk.

column1: add "chaintool new"
column29: Would be nice if the tooling could emit a skeleton project to get things started, similar to "lein new".

column1: Need to support chaincode events
Upgrade dependencies to latest releases
column29: Many of the dependencies have been upgraded since our last release.  We should ensure we use the latest where appropriate to pick up any bug fixes.

column1: Need to add channel support for chaincode to chaincode interfaces
column29: as of v0.10.2-SNAPSHOT, we emit channel compliant code but assume that the caller wishes to send a request to another chaincode within the same channel.  This might not always be the case, so we need to think about how to expose channel selection to the caller.

column1: Support (refresh) operation within REPL
column29: Development iteration within the REPL is easier when we include org.clojure/tools.namespace and user.clj helpers, like (refresh).

column1: Update chaintool dependencies
column29:
Running 'lein ancient' indicates there are more updates to our dependencies.

 
{code:java}
$ lein ancient
[org.clojure/clojure "1.9.0"] is available but we use "1.8.0" (use :check-clojure to upgrade)
[org.clojure/data.codec "0.1.1"] is available but we use "0.1.0"
[instaparse "1.4.8"] is available but we use "1.4.7"
[commons-io "2.6"] is available but we use "2.5"
[org.tukaani/xz "1.8"] is available but we use "1.6"
[org.apache.commons/commons-compress "1.16.1"] is available but we use "1.14"
[pandect "0.6.1"] is available but we use "0.5.4"
[clj-http "3.8.0"] is available but we use "3.7.0"

{code}
 

We will update those that do not pose a problem.  For instance, we know that pandect v0.6 requires some steps which are we not yet willing to take.  There may be others that we will evaluate and exclude, TBD

column1: Port example02 clients to v1.0.0-beta
Add support for proto3 constructs/types, including map
column29: Currently chaintool proto <filename.cci> will fail if using map

column1: Expose the mapping from function ids to Tx/Query names for the chaincode application to use
column29:
This desire is mostly based around logging. I want (some) log messages from the chaincode to state the chaincode-operation they are a part of. Currently, I can only log stub.GetStringArgs()[0], which looks something like "com.myorg.chaincode.myapp/txn/1". I would rather log that the message is coming from a "MyBusinessProcess" transaction.

As I understand it chaintool is responsible is mapping function identifiers to function names, so it would be nice if it provided a way for the application to apply that mapping to the introspection data it has access to.

column1: Add "chaintool deps" and remove implicit deps from "build"
column29: It would be better if we do not implicitly download dependencies during 'chaintool build'.  Therefore, create an explicit 'chaintool deps'

column1: Release chaintool v1.0.1
column29: Create a new release with a rollup of fixes since v1.0.0

column1: Chaintool - Chaintool Build fails with windows formatted cci files
column29:
"chaintool build" cmd fails with cci files generated on a windows filesystem

Other chaintool commands may also require windows file preprocessing in order to complete succesffully whend ealing with windows OS file encoding.

Attachement is a cci file that demonstrates the break issue.

column1: golang STG template should use consistent TAB for indent
column29: The indent style in the golang.stg generator template is inconsistent.  Since the golang gofmt standard seems to be TAB characters, we should convert the file to be as conforming as possible to the goland standard.

column1: chaintool: Improve "getting started" documentation
Documentation should reference proto3 specification in a clear way
column29: The grammar for CCI closesly models proto3, but this is not called out in a clear manner. We should make sure this is clear and provide reference links, etc.

column1: IV should be passed into NewAES256EncrypterECDSASignerEntity
column29:
IV is not in in the NewAES256EncrypterECDSASignerEntity's input parameter list,which leads to the error: 

2018/11/27 02:21:38 Failed to create account: endorsement validation failed: Endorser Client Status Code: (3) ENDORSEMENT_MISMATCH. Description: ProposalResponsePayloads do not match

 

FYI., the [doc|[http://example.com|https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/tree/release-1.3/examples/chaincode/go/enccc_example]] mentions:

...This call will encrypt using a random IV. This may be undesirable for instance if the chaincode invocation needs to be endorsed by multiple peers since it would cause the endorsement of conflicting read/write sets. It is possible to encrypt deterministically by specifying the IV, as follows: at first the IV must be created...

column1: Auto-vendoring causes deployment failure in latest chaintool

column1: Use ./autodeps instead of ./src/chaincode/vendor
column29: the problem with ./src/chaincode/vendor is that it makes the resources unavailable to the generated code such as build/src/hyperledger/cci/* .  We can correct this by storing the code in a normal $GOPATH rather than vendoring it under the chaincode.

column1: Disregard the GOPATH during 'buildcar' operations
column29: We want "chaintool buildcar" to only use its encapsulated dependencies, rather than taking anything from the environment.  Therefore, lets disable the GOPATH import during buildcar.
column104: 16/Sep/17 12:38 AM;greg.haskins;Turns out that this may not be necessary.  The GOPATH has the local versions first, and this seems to suitably eclipse the ccenv provided variants.  Closing for now.;;;

column1: Integrate fabric-chaintool SCC support into fabric build
Fix SCC support in chaintool
column29: Numerous changes have occurred in SCC since the original SCC support was added to chaintool.  This task will capture the fixes to make chaintool support SCC in v1.2+ code base

column1: Add support for compiling SCC code with chaintool
column29: The "peer" target should invoke a pre-compilaton task to run chaintool against any compatible SCCs to generate their interface code prior to running "go build".

column1: Incorrect license in file.
column29:
package.json says:

  "license": "ISC"

 

The correct license is Apache 2.
 * fabric-chaintool/examples/example02/client/nodejs/package.json
column54: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Some examples need updated license
column29:
Some files appear to be original to Hyperledger, but contain license headers indicating that they were contributed to the Apache Software Foundation under a CLA. If these files are in fact original to Hyperledger, then this header should be replaced with either the standard Apache-2.0 license notice, and/or with a short-form ID:
SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0

fabric-chaintool/examples/example02/app/src/chaincode/chaincode_example02.go
fabric-chaintool/examples/invoker/src/chaincode/chaincode.go
fabric-chaintool/examples/parameterless/src/chaincode/main.go
fabric-chaintool/examples/sample_syscc/sample_syscc.go
